thread.title: Cory Bernardi to split from Liberals this week: reports - Yahoo7
thread.title_full: Cory Bernardi to split from Liberals this week: reports - Yahoo7

author: Aap On February
title: Cory Bernardi to split from Liberals this week: reports - Yahoo7
text:
Share Cory Bernardi to split from Liberals this week: reports - Yahoo7 Conservative Liberal senator Cory Bernardi is set to quit the coalition within days to form his own political party. Close News Break - February 6 UP NEXT VIDEO Sydney heatwave continues while Melbourne is hit by heavy rain, Coalition support plunges, Trump travel ban blocked, massive cocaine bust, and more... News Break - February 6 
Both the ABC and News Corp commentator Andrew Bolt say the South Australian is ready to make his long-anticipated move this week as parliament returns from its long summer break. 
The new party would be based on his Australian Conservatives movement, which already has more than 50,000 members, Bolt said. Cory Bernardi is set to split from the Liberal Party this week. Photo: AAP 
"Bernardi has turned down all interviews lately, which is significant, but the logic all points to him breaking away soon," Bolt wrote. 
The ABC has reported on Monday morning the senator will walk out of the Liberal Party within the next 48 hours. 
Fellow SA Liberal Simon Birmingham played down a possible defection, citing his colleague's recent comments. Liberal Senator Simon Birmingham has played down Mr Bernardi's possible defection. Photo: AAP 
"Every comment I've ever seen Cory make, including over recent months, has been about the importance of Liberals, Nationals, conservatives -- all those in the right of centre -- working together and working as a strong Coalition," he said. 
"I'm confident that Cory will stand by his words." 
Cabinet colleague Matt Canavan said "of course" he wanted Senator Bernardi to stay in the coalition. 
"I love all members of our team and sometimes you don't agree with every member of your team but it's a great team and I hope we keep it together," he told reporters in Canberra. Cory Bernardi has been expected to leave the Liberal Party for some time. Photo: AAP 
Labor frontbencher Tony Burke wasn't surprised about the reports. 
"We've been watching a split in the coalition for more than a year now and it's going to continue to unravel," he said. 
Cabinet minister Steve Ciobo dismissed suggestions Senator Bernardi's defection would destabilise the government. 
"What Australia needs is a strong, stable plan for economic growth and jobs," he told reporters. 
Treasurer Scott Morrison suggested the senator was being egged on by others. 
"Lets' see what he announces, if he announces anything at all," Mr Morrison told Ray Hadley on Radio 2GB.
